synonyms: Neuropathy of the posterior tibial nerve and its branches

synonyms-with-source.name: Neuropathy of the posterior tibial nerve and its branches

resource descriptions.descriptionText: PubMed is a searchable database of medical literature and lists journal articles that discuss Tarsal tunnel syndrome. Click on the link to view a sample search on this topic.

The National Organization for Rare Disorders (NORD) has a report for patients and families about this condition. NORD is a patient advocacy organization for individuals with rare diseases and the organizations that serve them.
MedlinePlus was designed by the National Library of Medicine to help you research your health questions, and it provides more information about this topic.
Medscape Reference provides information on this topic. You may need to register to view the medical textbook, but registration is free.

The Monarch Initiative brings together data about this condition from humans and other species to help physicians and biomedical researchers. Monarch’s tools are designed to make it easier to compare the signs and symptoms (phenotypes) of different diseases and discover common features. This initiative is a collaboration between several academic institutions across the world and is funded by the National Institutes of Health. Visit the website to explore the biology of this condition.

overviewQuestion.answerText: Tarsal tunnel syndrome is a nerve disorder that is characterized by pain in the ankle, foot, and toes. This condition is caused by compression of the posterior tibial nerve, which runs through a canal near the heel into the sole of the foot. When tissues around this nerve become inflamed, they can press on the nerve and cause the pain associated with tarsal tunnel syndrome.[203]

basicQuestions.questionText: What symptoms are commonly seen in tarsal tunnel syndrome?
basicQuestions.answerText: The symptoms of tarsal tunnel syndrome can vary from person to person. The most common symptom of tarsal tunnel syndrome is foot and ankle pain. Individuals may also experience a burning or tingling sensation and numbness.[204] These symptoms may occur when a person stands, walks, or wears a particular type of shoe.[203] Pain usually worsens during walking and is relieved by rest.[203]

references.bookWebsiteJournalTitle: The Merck Manual Home Health Handbook
American College of Foot and Ankle Surgeons Web site

basicQuestions.answerText: There are a variety of factors that may cause tarsal tunnel syndrome. These may include repetitive stress with activities, trauma (e.g., crush injury, stretch injury, fractures, ankle dislocations or sprains), flat feet, and excess weight. Additionally, any lesion that occupies space within the tarsal tunnel region may cause pressure on the nerve and subsequent symptoms. Examples include tendonitis, hematoma, tumor, varicose veins, and lower extremity edema.[204]

references.bookWebsiteJournalTitle: American College of Foot and Ankle Surgeons Web site

basicQuestions.questionText: What treatment is available for tarsal tunnel syndrome?
basicQuestions.answerText:
While we do not provide medical advice, the following have been reported as treatment options for tarsal tunnel syndrome.[204] Individuals should discuss the various treatment options with their personal healthcare provider.

  • Rest and ice
  • Oral pain medications
  • Steroid injections
  • Local anesthetics
  • Physical therapy
  • Immobilization
  • Orthotic devices
  • Decompression surgery

references.bookWebsiteJournalTitle: American College of Foot and Ankle Surgeons Web site

basicQuestions.questionText: What is the prevalence of tarsal tunnel syndrome?
basicQuestions.answerText: The incidence and prevalence of tarsal tunnel syndrome is unknown.[205][8584]

caseQuestions.questionText: What is the prevalence of tarsal tunnel syndrome?
caseQuestions.answerText: The incidence and prevalence of tarsal tunnel syndrome is unknown.[205][8584]

gardCases.abbreviatedInquiry: My daughter's doctor is recommending surgery to remove the bone and lengthen the nerve.  I was reading that this surgery has a 13 percent complication rate.  Could you tell me what these complications might be?

caseQuestions.questionText: What complications are associated with tarsal tunnel decompression surgery?
caseQuestions.answerText: While we cannot address all of the complications associated with surgery for tarsal tunnel syndrome, the medical literature indicates that complications may include nerve or artery laceration and plantar fasciitis.[205] One small study reviewed the results of 30 patients who underwent decompression surgery for tarsal tunnel syndrome and reported a 13 percent complication rate.[229] In this study, three individuals had wound infections and one person had a delay in wound healing. We recommend consulting with your surgical team for more information on the potential complications of tarsal tunnel decompression surgery.

references.bookWebsiteJournalTitle: Pfeiffer WH, Cracchiolo A 3rd. Clinical results after tarsal tunnel decompression. J Bone Joint Surg Am. 1994;76:1222-1230. PubMed

news.title: NIH-Supported Research Survey to Examine Impact of COVID-19 on Rare Diseases Community
news.description: The NIH-funded Rare Diseases Clinical Research Network (RDCRN) has launched an online research survey to find out how the COVID-19 pandemic is impacting individuals with rare diseases, their families and their caregivers. Your participation can help the rare disease research community shed light on the needs of people with rare diseases during this and other potential health crises, in addition to informing future research efforts. The survey must be completed by December 15, 2020.
